About Our Models


Tuning of hyperparameters allows the machine learning model to produce the most accurate results possible. We decided to focus on max_depth (the max number of levels in each decision tree), min_samples_leaf (min number of data points allowed in a leaf node), and random_state. Random_state ensures that the splits that you generate are reproducible. Scikit-learn uses random permutations to generate the splits. The random_state that you provide is used as a seed to the random number generator. This ensures that the random numbers are generated in the same order.
The results of the train and test model are mean squared error and r squared, respectively. The mean squared error is the average squared difference between the estimated values and the actual value. The smaller this number is, the more accurate the model is. The r squared value shows the accuracy of the model's ability to predict the training data's regression line. In this case, the closer to the r squared is to 1, the better; however, the r squared can be negative. If an r squared is negative, the model's prediction tends to be less accurate than the mean of the model. In most cases, this would mean that the model does not accurately predict or fit the data. However, in the case of stock market data, it is very difficult to predict the future because past performance does not necessarily predict future performance. Although a negative r squared is typically considered an unsuccessful test, it doesn't guarantee that the model is inaccurate, it is just less confident in its prediction.
A max_depth of 100 proved to be less accurate than a max_depth of 8. It is important to remember that these results are randomized. A higher max_depth is not necessarily a determinant of a more accurate model, finding the correct depth is more important than using a ridiculously high number (and therefore a great deal of computing power). This is why it is called hyperparameter "tuning." It is typically suggested to use a random_state of less than 40, as it will not drastically change the results with a higher number while using more computer power. However, this does show that a minimum threshold needs to be reached before having accurate data. A random state of 2 was wildly inaccurate.
